title: How to Make Fresh Neem Leaves Paste

steps.headline: Soak 7–8 neem leaves in warm water until they feel soft.
steps.description: Fill a small bowl with warm water from your faucet and completely submerge your neem leaves. Keep the leaves in the bowl for about 15–20 minutes so they can absorb the water and soften. When the leaves feel soft to the touch, remove them and shake off any excess water so they aren’t dripping wet.You can get fresh neem leaves in many supermarkets or foreign food stores. If you don’t have fresh neem leaves available, you can also use ground neem leaves. You do not need to soak ground neem leaves beforehand.

steps.headline: Grind the leaves into a paste with a mortar and pestle.
steps.description: Place the wet leaves into the mortar, which is the piece that looks like a stone bowl. Push the pestle, which is a long grinding stone with a rounded edge, onto the leaves and twist it to break them down. Continue mashing and grinding the leaves with the pestle until they form a thick paste-like consistency. Make sure all of the leaves are evenly ground so the paste applies easily.You can buy a mortar and pestle from most cooking supply stores. You may also dry neem leaves if you want to make a neem powder instead.Variation: If you don’t have a mortar and pestle, you can also put the leaves directly in your blender and pulse them at a medium speed.

steps.headline: Add 1 tsp (3 g) of ground turmeric to the paste to help reduce blemishes.
steps.description: Turmeric has anti-inflammatory properties that can make acne or blemishes shrink. Scoop out 1 teaspoon (3 g) of ground turmeric and mix it into your paste. Use a spoon or your pestle to stir the mixture until it’s thoroughly combined.You do not need to use turmeric in your neem paste if you don’t want to. Turmeric may stain your skin yellow if you use it.

steps.headline: Stir 1 US tbsp (15 ml) of honey into the paste to act as a moisturizer.
steps.description: You can use any honey you normally would for cooking. Pour the honey directly in with the paste and use a spoon to mix it. Continue stirring the paste until you can easily spread it around with your finger.You do not need to put honey in your neem leaf paste if you don’t want. Don’t use honey if you have oily skin since it could make your skin appear oilier.

steps.headline: Mix in 1 US tbsp (15 ml) of yogurt if you want glowing skin.
steps.description: Use plain, unflavored yogurt to use with your neem leaf paste. Use your pestle or a spoon to stir the yogurt in with the rest of the mixture. Continue mixing until the paste has a thick consistency.You don’t need to use yogurt if you don’t want to. Only use new yogurt in your neem leaf paste so you don’t contaminate it with bacteria.

steps.headline: Wash your face with water and cleanser first.
steps.description: Wet your face with warm water to open your pores and massage your regular facial cleanser into your skin. Scrub the cleanser into your skin with a washcloth if you want a deeper clean. Once you wash your entire face, rinse the cleanser off with warm water to remove the suds. Pat your face with a towel until it’s dry.If you don’t have time to wash your face, rinse it with warm water to remove any dirt or dust on the surface of your skin.

steps.headline: Spread the neem paste on your face.
steps.description: Dip your finger in the neem paste and rub it in your palms so it’s easier to spread. Apply the neem paste on your face, making sure to leave the skin around your eyes and mouth exposed. Work the paste into your skin as much as you can so it doesn’t drip off your face.Use a soft cosmetics brush or paintbrush to spread the paste if you don’t want to get your hands dirty or sticky. If you get any of the neem leaf paste in your eyes, rinse them out immediately to reduce any irritation. If you have any leftover paste, you can save it in an airtight container in your fridge for 2–3 days. If it starts to turn brown or develops a strong odor, throw it away.Tip: Test the neem leaf paste on a small section of skin on your hand to see if you have any allergic reactions. If you do, don’t apply the paste to your face.

steps.headline: Leave the paste on your skin for 15–20 minutes.
steps.description: Don’t touch your face while you have the neem leaf paste on or else it won’t be as effective. Relax while you have the paste on or do simple things around the house, like browsing online or reading a book. After about 15–20 minutes, the neem leaf paste will start to lose its effect.Keeping neem leaf paste on your skin for longer won’t have any negative effects, but you won’t notice much difference.

steps.headline: Rinse off the neem paste with clean water.
steps.description: Start by rinsing your face with warm water so the paste comes off easier. Rub your face with a washcloth or towel to remove any paste that’s still stuck. Turn the water down so it gets cold and rinse your face again to help close your pores and keep dirt out.Avoid touching your face after you clean it with the paste since your hands may be dirty.

steps.headline: Use neem leaf paste up to 3 times per week.
steps.description: Leave at least 1 day in between each time you use neem leaf paste and pick times when you aren’t busy with other tasks. Use fresh leaves each time you make the paste so it's the most effective. Continue using the neem leaf paste until your face looks clean and blemish-free!

text: Mixing the Neem Paste Soak 7–8 neem leaves in warm water until they feel soft. Fill a small bowl with warm water from your faucet and completely submerge your neem leaves. Keep the leaves in the bowl for about 15–20 minutes so they can absorb the water and soften. When the leaves feel soft to the touch, remove them and shake off any excess water so they aren’t dripping wet.You can get fresh neem leaves in many supermarkets or foreign food stores. If you don’t have fresh neem leaves available, you can also use ground neem leaves. You do not need to soak ground neem leaves beforehand. Grind the leaves into a paste with a mortar and pestle. Place the wet leaves into the mortar, which is the piece that looks like a stone bowl. Push the pestle, which is a long grinding stone with a rounded edge, onto the leaves and twist it to break them down. Continue mashing and grinding the leaves with the pestle until they form a thick paste-like consistency. Make sure all of the leaves are evenly ground so the paste applies easily.You can buy a mortar and pestle from most cooking supply stores. You may also dry neem leaves if you want to make a neem powder instead.Variation: If you don’t have a mortar and pestle, you can also put the leaves directly in your blender and pulse them at a medium speed. Add 1 tsp (3 g) of ground turmeric to the paste to help reduce blemishes. Turmeric has anti-inflammatory properties that can make acne or blemishes shrink. Scoop out 1 teaspoon (3 g) of ground turmeric and mix it into your paste. Use a spoon or your pestle to stir the mixture until it’s thoroughly combined.You do not need to use turmeric in your neem paste if you don’t want to. Turmeric may stain your skin yellow if you use it. Stir 1 US tbsp (15 ml) of honey into the paste to act as a moisturizer. You can use any honey you normally would for cooking. Pour the honey directly in with the paste and use a spoon to mix it. Continue stirring the paste until you can easily spread it around with your finger.You do not need to put honey in your neem leaf paste if you don’t want. Don’t use honey if you have oily skin since it could make your skin appear oilier. Mix in 1 US tbsp (15 ml) of yogurt if you want glowing skin. Use plain, unflavored yogurt to use with your neem leaf paste. Use your pestle or a spoon to stir the yogurt in with the rest of the mixture. Continue mixing until the paste has a thick consistency.You don’t need to use yogurt if you don’t want to. Only use new yogurt in your neem leaf paste so you don’t contaminate it with bacteria. Applying the Paste Wash your face with water and cleanser first. Wet your face with warm water to open your pores and massage your regular facial cleanser into your skin. Scrub the cleanser into your skin with a washcloth if you want a deeper clean. Once you wash your entire face, rinse the cleanser off with warm water to remove the suds. Pat your face with a towel until it’s dry.If you don’t have time to wash your face, rinse it with warm water to remove any dirt or dust on the surface of your skin. Spread the neem paste on your face. Dip your finger in the neem paste and rub it in your palms so it’s easier to spread. Apply the neem paste on your face, making sure to leave the skin around your eyes and mouth exposed. Work the paste into your skin as much as you can so it doesn’t drip off your face.Use a soft cosmetics brush or paintbrush to spread the paste if you don’t want to get your hands dirty or sticky. If you get any of the neem leaf paste in your eyes, rinse them out immediately to reduce any irritation. If you have any leftover paste, you can save it in an airtight container in your fridge for 2–3 days. If it starts to turn brown or develops a strong odor, throw it away.Tip: Test the neem leaf paste on a small section of skin on your hand to see if you have any allergic reactions. If you do, don’t apply the paste to your face. Leave the paste on your skin for 15–20 minutes. Don’t touch your face while you have the neem leaf paste on or else it won’t be as effective. Relax while you have the paste on or do simple things around the house, like browsing online or reading a book. After about 15–20 minutes, the neem leaf paste will start to lose its effect.Keeping neem leaf paste on your skin for longer won’t have any negative effects, but you won’t notice much difference. Rinse off the neem paste with clean water. Start by rinsing your face with warm water so the paste comes off easier. Rub your face with a washcloth or towel to remove any paste that’s still stuck. Turn the water down so it gets cold and rinse your face again to help close your pores and keep dirt out.Avoid touching your face after you clean it with the paste since your hands may be dirty. Use neem leaf paste up to 3 times per week. Leave at least 1 day in between each time you use neem leaf paste and pick times when you aren’t busy with other tasks. Use fresh leaves each time you make the paste so it's the most effective. Continue using the neem leaf paste until your face looks clean and blemish-free!

Fill a small bowl with warm water from your faucet and completely submerge your neem leaves.
Keep the leaves in the bowl for about 15–20 minutes so they can absorb the water and soften.
When the leaves feel soft to the touch, remove them and shake off any excess water so they aren’t dripping wet.You can get fresh neem leaves in many supermarkets or foreign food stores.
If you don’t have fresh neem leaves available, you can also use ground neem leaves.
You do not need to soak ground neem leaves beforehand.
Grind the leaves into a paste with a mortar and pestle.
Place the wet leaves into the mortar, which is the piece that looks like a stone bowl.
Push the pestle, which is a long grinding stone with a rounded edge, onto the leaves and twist it to break them down.
Continue mashing and grinding the leaves with the pestle until they form a thick paste-like consistency.
Make sure all of the leaves are evenly ground so the paste applies easily.You can buy a mortar and pestle from most cooking supply stores.

You may also dry neem leaves if you want to make a neem powder instead.Variation: If you don’t have a mortar and pestle, you can also put the leaves directly in your blender and pulse them at a medium speed.
Add 1 tsp (3 g) of ground turmeric to the paste to help reduce blemishes.
Turmeric has anti-inflammatory properties that can make acne or blemishes shrink.
Scoop out 1 teaspoon (3 g) of ground turmeric and mix it into your paste.
Use a spoon or your pestle to stir the mixture until it’s thoroughly combined.You do not need to use turmeric in your neem paste if you don’t want to.
Turmeric may stain your skin yellow if you use it.
Stir 1 US tbsp (15 ml) of honey into the paste to act as a moisturizer.
You can use any honey you normally would for cooking.
Pour the honey directly in with the paste and use a spoon to mix it.
Continue stirring the paste until you can easily spread it around with your finger.You do not need to put honey in your neem leaf paste if you don’t want.
Don’t use honey if you have oily skin since it could make your skin appear oilier.
Mix in 1 US tbsp (15 ml) of yogurt if you want glowing skin.
Use plain, unflavored yogurt to use with your neem leaf paste.
Use your pestle or a spoon to stir the yogurt in with the rest of the mixture.
Continue mixing until the paste has a thick consistency.You don’t need to use yogurt if you don’t want to.
Only use new yogurt in your neem leaf paste so you don’t contaminate it with bacteria.
Applying the Paste Wash your face with water and cleanser first.
Wet your face with warm water to open your pores and massage your regular facial cleanser into your skin.
Scrub the cleanser into your skin with a washcloth if you want a deeper clean.
Once you wash your entire face, rinse the cleanser off with warm water to remove the suds.
Pat your face with a towel until it’s dry.If you don’t have time to wash your face, rinse it with warm water to remove any dirt or dust on the surface of your skin.
Spread the neem paste on your face.
Dip your finger in the neem paste and rub it in your palms so it’s easier to spread.
Apply the neem paste on your face, making sure to leave the skin around your eyes and mouth exposed.
Work the paste into your skin as much as you can so it doesn’t drip off your face.Use a soft cosmetics brush or paintbrush to spread the paste if you don’t want to get your hands dirty or sticky.
If you get any of the neem leaf paste in your eyes, rinse them out immediately to reduce any irritation.
If you have any leftover paste, you can save it in an airtight container in your fridge for 2–3 days.
If it starts to turn brown or develops a strong odor, throw it away.Tip: Test the neem leaf paste on a small section of skin on your hand to see if you have any allergic reactions.
If you do, don’t apply the paste to your face.
Leave the paste on your skin for 15–20 minutes.
Don’t touch your face while you have the neem leaf paste on or else it won’t be as effective.
Relax while you have the paste on or do simple things around the house, like browsing online or reading a book.
After about 15–20 minutes, the neem leaf paste will start to lose its effect.Keeping neem leaf paste on your skin for longer won’t have any negative effects, but you won’t notice much difference.
Rinse off the neem paste with clean water.
Start by rinsing your face with warm water so the paste comes off easier.
Rub your face with a washcloth or towel to remove any paste that’s still stuck.
Turn the water down so it gets cold and rinse your face again to help close your pores and keep dirt out.Avoid touching your face after you clean it with the paste since your hands may be dirty.
Use neem leaf paste up to 3 times per week.
Leave at least 1 day in between each time you use neem leaf paste and pick times when you aren’t busy with other tasks.
Use fresh leaves each time you make the paste so it's the most effective.
Continue using the neem leaf paste until your face looks clean and blemish-free!
